title: Standards, Bedrock For Development - Hon. Ekow Spio-Gabrah
text:
20 October 2015 10:20 CET Standards, Bedrock For Development - Hon. Ekow Spio-Gabrah By Emmanuel Amoquandoh 
The Minister for Trade and Industry Hon. Ekow Spio-Gabrah has mentioned that the bedrock of development for every nation is the application of standards. 
Speaking at the 46 th celebration of World Standards Day, on the theme, “Standards, the World’s Common Language”, the Chief Director for the Ministry of Trade and Industry, Dawarnoba Baeka, who delivered the speech on behalf of the Minister, commended the Ghana Standards Authority (GSA) for their role towards the development and promotion of standards. 
He said every country is conscious about the safety of its people, and would not encourage sub-standard products to enter its destination, which explains the rigid measures put in place by the different countries in the world to prevent the importation of sub-standard products. 
Pledging the Ministry’s support to promote local and foreign trade as well as industrial growth to promote the welfare of Ghanaians and other nationals, he said the Ministry would support GSA to promote trade and industrial growth, ensuring that goods that are exported from Ghana to other countries comply with standards in those countries. 
“In the same way, it is just fair and appropriate that goods imported into Ghana are also made to conform to applicable standards in this country”, he said, and added, the world would enjoy quality products from various parts to different destination points for the consumption of consumers in different locations of the world. 
He charged the public to, also pay critical attention to what they consume since sub-standard products can threaten their lives because, applying standards helps to ensure safety and health of consumers as well as protecting the environment. 
The Executive Director of the Ghana Standards Authority (GSA), Dr. George Ben Crentsil, stated international co-operation in standardisation programmes is very crucial because activities in any part of the world everyone, indicating that all countries whether developed or developing depends on each other for their own common good. 
He mentioned that, credit cards and all other forms of international cards are able to function anywhere in the word because of standards. Likewise, home appliances are able to function properly when they are fixed to the supportive sockets. 
Dr. Crentsil mentioned that standards help people to understand important information on quality despite language barriers, no matter the display of graphical symbols. He said standards on graphical symbols on emergency evacuation signs or electrical equipments give instructional directives for the same message to promote better understand. 
He stated that because of standards, computers are able to send documents to a printer though the computers come from different manufacturer, because, standards set out the common parameters for products to work effectively with other like products. 
Dr. Crentsil stated that when manufacturers come out with quality products for consumers it contributes positively to socio-economic development, which in turn leads to quality life and higher standard of living in various parts of the world. 
The chairman for the occasion, Prof. Esther Sakyi-Dawson stated that adhering to standards help to make life less chaotic. 
She urged that the informal sector must also include standards in their day-to-day activities to make made-in-Ghana goods a reality. 
Participants at the 46 th celebration of the World Standards Day were drawn from both the formal and informal sector. 
Solidarity messages from bodies of professional associations and other companies centred on ensuring good standards for economic development and advancing technology to support the country. 
They included, the Association of Ghana Industries (AGI), National Petroleum Authority (NPA), Energy Commission and Nestle Ghana. 
The Rest are the Public Utilities Regulatory Authority (PURC) and the Ghana Institution of Engineers.
